I remind honourable senators that 19,000 prescriptions for intal have been lodged with the Commonwealth doctors for approval and none of them has been refused. I mentioned this last time I spoke on this matter. Why do we have to doit?
- It makes work.

talker.party: IND; AP from Aug. 1969; IND from Jan. 1970
talker.name: TURNBULL, Reginald
Senator TURNBULL

talk.start.para: -That is right.

speech.para: Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: - Order! It being 10.30 p.m., in conformity with the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate, I formally put the question:

quote.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice:

quote.para: Does the Government of the People's Republic of China consider the effects of nuclear fall-out to be of little significance to health, or does it display a callous disregard for the health and welfare of its people.

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Australian Government does not presume to speak for the Government of China on this matter.

talk.start.para: -On 22 August 1973, Senator Withers asked the following question, without notice:

quote.para: Why are government rents rising while rental for privately owned houses must remain static. Is this another example of the Government's double standards.

question.para: The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: Government house rentals in the A.C.T. have been below an economic level for many years, which meant that housing operations were being conducted at a loss met by Australian taxpayers.

The proposed increase is intended to do no more than bring rentals of Government houses to an economic level. Even at the increased level they will still be low by comparison with rentals charged for privately owned accommodation in the A.C.T.

talk.start.para: -On 28 August 1973, Senator Greenwood asked the following question, without notice:

quote.para: Why has the Minister for the Capital Territory departed from the practice of the previous Government and declined to submit all proposed Ordinances to the Advisory Council of the A.C.T.

question.para: The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The question has no foundation in fact. Since January 1973 I have submitted 19 Ordinances to Council in draft. Other Ministers involved in the administration of Canberra also follow a similar course.

talk.start.para: -On 28 August 1973, Senator Guilfoyle asked me a question without notice concerning Lending Organisations. The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The Treasury and Reserve Bank are currently undertaking a detailed study of the various aspects of the regulation of nonbank financial intermediaries. When that examination is completed the Government will decide what measures are desirable in the interests of the community. It is hoped that, at an appropriate time, consultations can take place with the relevant State authorities regarding permanent building societies and other financial institutions covered by State legislation that would come within Australian Government legislation.

question.para: French Nuclear Tests: Reports on Fall-out (Question No. 220)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science, upon notice:

quote.para: What was the wording of the most official report to the Commonwealth Government on the effect on Australia and its inhabitants of any nuclear test carried out by the French Government in the Pacific area.

talk.start.para: - The Minister for the Environment and Conservation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: Reports on the effects upon the Australian population of each series of French nuclear tests in the Pacific have been made public by tabling in the Parliament or release to the press after the monitoring program for each series has been completed. The latest report by the Australian Academy of Science entitled The Biological Effects of Nuclear Explosion FalloutReport to the Prime Minister (April 1973) was presented in the Senate by my colleague, the Attorney-General, on 2 May 1973.

subdebateinfo.title: National Health and Medical Research Council: Recommendations (Question No. 365)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice:

item.para: 1 ) Is the Minister aware of the recommendations of the National Health and Medical Research Council in November 1972 as to national emission standards for smoke, solid particles and soot.
What action has been taken by the Australian Government and by each of the State Governments with respect to these standards.
Does the Minister propose to adopt these standards by ordinance in the Australian Capital Territory; if so, when.

talk.start.para: - The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: Yes.

The recommendations of the National Health and Medical Research Council of November 1 972 relating to national emission standards for air pollutants is being considered by the Emission Standards Sub-Committee of the Australian Environment Council.

Further action with respect to the adoption of these standards by legislation will depend on the advice given to the Government by the Australian Environment Council. Investigations are being conducted into air quality factors in and around Canberra.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Customs and Excise, upon notice:

item.para: 1 ) Did the present Government, when in opposition, assert that if elected to the Treasury benches it would promptly remove the existing 25 cents per gallon excise charge applicable to wine, and would not impose any alternative form of taxation on the wine industry.

How can the Government reconcile this undertaking with its action in removing the duty differential favouring brandy and the imposition of a tax adding approximately $5 per gallon on brandy, a product vital to the well-being of the grape-growing and wine-making industries.

Does the Minister realise the severity of the increase and the crippling effect it will have on the industry; if so, will immediate consideration be given to rectifying the position and honouring the election promise.

talk.start.para: - The answer which I have is as follows:

item.para: This Government, when in opposition, pledged to remove the excise on wine introduced in 1970 by the previous Government. This pledge was carried out within a week of this Government taking up office in December last

Brandy has, for nearly 20 years, been subjected to a significantly lower rate of excise than have other competitive spirits. There is no connection between phasing out this differential over three years as announced by the Honourable the Treasurer, and the Government's action in eliminating the excise on wine.

There is no election promise to honour. I am aware of the benefits that the differential has given to the brandy industry since 19S4 and the importance that that industry attaches to it. If the brandy industry can demonstrate that the cost of. production of brandy exceeds that of competitive spirits to an extent that some differential is both justified and necessary then it would follow that the industry had grounds to ask the Government to inquire into the need for tariff assistance.

subdebateinfo.title: Commonwealth Public Service Superannuation Scheme (Question No. 353)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice:

item.para: 1 ) What has been the cause, or causes of the surplus in the current Commonwealth Public Service superannuation scheme.
When will action be taken to refund this surplus to contributors.

talk.start.para: - The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: 1 ) The surplus in the Superannuation Fund as at 30 June 1967 is made up as set out hereunder.

subdebate.1.para: The reasons for the various items are as follows:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The bases of the recalculation of the liabilities of the Fund at 30 June 1962 for the purpose of the distribution, assumed interest would be earned at a rate of 5.5 per cent per annum for the next 10 years. In the event, the Fund barely achieved this rate.
b) The immediate loss on sale of assets will be more than compensated for in future years by a higher rate of interest on the reinvestment of the sale proceeds.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Section 147 provides for the Commonwealth to take over certain pension liabilities from the Fund in excess of the proportion of the pension equivalent to the contributions made by the relevant contributors.

item.label: (d)
item.para: The amounts of surplus and deficiency from the experience of contributors and pensioners have been calculated on the bases in use during the Quinquennium.

item.label: (e)
item.para: The Miscellaneous Items represent various amounts arising from the working of the Fund.

item.label: (f)
item.para: The transfer to the new valuation basis of 5 per cent per annum in lieu of 5.5 per cent per annum for the 10 years 1962-1972 and 4.5 per cent per annum thereafter has resulted in an adjustment in the actuarial reserves which would otherwise be required. The $14,779,000 surplus does not take into account the loss of $205,000 incurred after 30 June 1967 in respect of the conversion of units in force at that date to non-contributory units.

The President of the Superannuation Board has informed me that the surplus of assets over liabilities in the Fund as at 30 June 1967 ($14,779,000) reported to the Parliament on 8 March 1972 has been accumulated at interest and carried forward into the Valuation Balance Sheet for the Tenth Quinquennial Investigation as at 30 June 1972, to be added to any surplus amounts which may arise during that period. He states that a report from the Superannuation Board on this matter will be submitted to me in the near future.

talk.start.para: -On 29 August 1973, Senator Greenwood asked the following question, without notice:

quote.para: Is it a fact that the increases in the price of petrol, necessitated by the Government's budget proposals, have been approved by the Prices Justification Tribunal as able to be included in the petrol retailer's price of petrol throughout Australia. Is it not also a fact that the fixation of the price at which petrol may be sold in the Australian Capital Territory excludes the increase necessitated by the budget proposals. If so what is the reason for this discrimination.

question.para: The Minister for the Capital Territory has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: The Prices Justification Tribunal authorised the oil companies to pass on increases in excise, however, this in no way precludes the Tribunal from examining at any time in accordance with Section 16 of the Prices Justification Act 1973, the price and pricing structure of petrol. In the Australian Capital Territory the prices of petrol have been fixed at pre-budget levels. It is for the oil companies now to justify any higher prices they would otherwise charge.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice:

quote.para: Will the Treasurer provide an itemised statement of the funds paid out under the Export Incentive Grants Act for (a) the financial year 1971-72, and (b) for the financial year 1972-73, to date.
